nodes.text: Can Higgs Inflation be Saved with High-scale Supersymmetry ?
Sibo Zheng
Department of Physics, Chongqing University, Chongqing 401331, P. R. China
It is shown whether Higgs inflation can be saved with high-scale supersymmetry critically depends on the
magnitude of non-minimal coupling constant ξ. For small ξ ≤ 500, the threshold correction at scale MP /ξ
is constrained in high precision. Its magnitude is in the narrow range of (−0.03, −0.02) and (−0.05, −0.04)
for the wino and higgsino/singlino dark matter, respectively. While in the large ξ -region with ξ ≥ 104, such
high-scale supersymmetry is excluded by too large threshold correction as required by Higgs inflation.
I. INTRODUCTION
The collider facilities such as the Large Hadron Collider
(LHC) and astrophysical experiments are two main tools for
exploring new physics beyond the standard model (SM). Re-
cently, the Plank Collaboration, designed to detect the cosmic
microwave background (CMB) temperature anisotropy and
polarization, has reported the latest value of tensor-to-scalar
ratio r ≤ 0.11 at 95% CL [1, 2]. This data excludes a few
well known inflation models such as quadratic inflation, but
still allows some simple examples such as Starobinsky-like
inflation [3], α-attractor inflation [4] and Higgs inflation [5].
Among these survivors, Higgs inflation is rather special due
to two considerations. Firstly, there is only one new parameter
ξ in this model in the Lagrangian in this model, which reads
as in the Jordan frame,
Here, ξ measures the non-minimal coupling between Higgs
scalar h and gravity. It was found that the Higgs scalar po-
tential VE (h) in the Einstein frame rapidly approaches to a
ξ, and plateau potential in the large field region h > MP /
the model predicts that for e-foldings number N = 60,
which is in perfect agreement with the Plank 2015 data [1,
2]. In terms of the present cosmological data M in Eq.(1)
approximates to the reduced Plank mass MP = 2.4 × 1018
GeV for our present universe. Moreover, unlike Starobinsky-
like inflation or α-attractor inflation, it is obvious that Higgs
inflation is of special interest from the viewpoint of particle
physics.
Unfortunately, there are two subjects against the Higgs in-
In this letter, we consider saving the Higgs inflation with
high-scale supersymmetry (SUSY). High-scale SUSY can
provide the observed Higgs mass at the LHC and stable DM
candidate [15]. However, the detection of such models at col-
liders is unpromising. In this sense the astrophysical probe
is an important direction. Fortunately, they can be probed di-
rectly or indirectly in the light of the cosmological observa-
tions on the early universe [16, 17].
We identify the cut-off scale MP /ξ as the typical mass
scale ˜m in the SUSY mass spectrum. Above the scale ˜m =
MP /ξ supergravity is the natural ultra-violet (UV) comple-
tion, and for the matter content same as the next-to-minimal
SUSY model (NMSSM) it may maintain the plateau poten-
tial [18]. For earlier discussions, see [19–21]. On the other
hand, the SUSY dark matter (DM), whose mass is around the
weak scale, is the natural choice on the new fields added to the
SM below the cut-off scale ˜m. In this paper, we consider two
possibilities [15], where wino ˜w and higgsino/singlino mixing
state serves as the DM, respectively.
The paper is organized as follows. In the next section, we
discuss the RGE for λH in two classes of high-scale SUSY be-
low scale ˜m. In Section III, we discuss embedding the Higgs
inflation to supergravity, where we uncover the constraint on
parameters λH and ξ at the end of inflation hend = MP /
arising from the present cosmological data. In section IV, we
discuss the constraint on the SUSY mass spectrum in terms of
the constraint on the threshold correction to λH . Finally, we
flation. The first subject shows that the SM is not valid above
scale MP /ξ [6–8]. It implies that the plateau potential V (h)

λH at the weak scale is not large enough so that λH < 0 above
the high-energy scale 109 − 1011 GeV. The uncertainty about
this critical scale mainly arises from the the uncertainty of top
quark mass, as the renormalization group equation (RGE) for
λH is very sensitive to the top Yukawa coupling. Obviously,
positive λH is required during inflationary epoch. This prob-
lem can be solved through introducing some new fields into
the SM, which give rise to either correct threshold correction
to λH or slowing down the RG evaluation for λH along high
energy scale, see, .e.g., [13, 14].

The matter content of the effective theory at the intermedi-
ate scale is composed of SM fermions, squarks, gauginos and
electrically neutral scalars in the Higgs sector. The beta func-
tion coefficients bi for the SM gauge coupling in this effective
theory are given by, respectively,
where n = 3 is the number of SM fermion generations.
In terms of Eq.(13) and one-loop RGEs for λH and SM top
Yukawa coupling we show in Fig.3 the constraint on the mag-
nitude of δλH (mg1 , mg3 , m˜qi ) for the range 300 ≤ ξ ≤
50000. It is shown that the value for δ λH (mg1 , mg3 , m ˜qi )
as required by Higgs inflation is very sensitive to parameter ξ.
In the light of Fig.3 we conclude that for small non-minimal
coupling ξ ≤ 500, the threshold correction at scale MP /ξ
induced by Higgs inflation is about −0.03 ∼ −0.02 and
−0.05 ∼ −0.04 in wino and higgsino/singlino DM, respec-
tively. The uncertainties mainly arise from the uncertainty of
top quark pole mass. In the large ξ region with ξ ≥ 1 × 104,
the required threshold correction is ≤ −0.1, which is too large
to exclude such models.
V. DISCUSSION AND SUMMARY

So far we have only discussed the constraint on the thresh-
One may wonder whether adopting larger mt than 172.2
GeV can reduce the threshold correction in Fig.3 ? Fig.1 and
Fig.2 have shown that λH (MP − ϵ) becomes more negative
when one chooses larger mt, and the value of λ(MP /ξ + ϵ),
which is positive, will be smaller simultaneously. Therefore
the deviation to the threshold correction is not too obvious to
violate our conclusions.
In summary, the answer to the question whether Higgs in-
flation can be saved by high-scale SUSY critically depends on
the magnitude of ξ. For small non-minimal coupling ξ ≤ 500,
the threshold correction at scale MP /ξ required by Higgs
inflation is constrained in high precision, the magnitude of
which is about −0.03 ∼ −0.02 and −0.05 ∼ −0.04 for the
wino and higgsino/singlino DM, respectively. The uncertain-
ties mainly arise from the uncertainty of top quark pole mass.
This amount of threshold correction can be explained, for ex-
ample, for universal squark masses m ˜q ≃ MP6ξ with vanishing
At terms. For large ξ ∼ 104, the required threshold correc-
tion is smaller than ≃ −0.1, which excludes such high-scale
SUSY. Finally, we believe our analysis can be applied to Split
SUSY, although this model is more complicated in compared
with what have been discussed here.
